title: Obama, Riding High, Could Be the Ace in Clinton’s Pocket
abstract: The president may be able to help most by using his renewed popularity to rouse the elements of the Democratic coalition that twice elected him.

multimedia_item.caption: President Obama has seen his approval rating creep past 50 percent this year. For Democrats hoping to hold the White House, that has come at just the right time.

title: Wall St. Is Mixed in Early Trading
abstract: Consumer spending in the United States rose 1 percent in April, the largest amount in more than six years, led by a big jump in purchases of autos and other durable goods.

title: Software for Stopping Freedom
abstract: Software companies are selling spying and hacking tools to governments interested in quashing human-rights workers, political dissidents and journalists.

title: Getting Up Close With the iOS Camera
abstract: Apple’s built-in camera app for its iOS devices includes controls for zooming and other fine-tuning — if you know where to tap.

multimedia_item.caption: When using the iOS 9 Camera app, pinch your fingers on the screen to see a zoom slider appear. You can adjust the exposure by tapping an area of the screen and sliding the sun icon up or down.

title: Medieval Festival in Rebellious Catalonia Takes on Modern Meaning
abstract: The Patum, a spectacular centuries-old event in Berga, has come to symbolize Spain’s contemporary political and social struggles.

link.suggested_link_text: Catalan Independence Bid Looms Over Spain’s Coalition Efforts
Azorean Diaspora Can’t Resist the Powerful Pull of Home
Pillars of Holy Week Processions Put Teamwork and Brawn on Display

multimedia_item.caption: Performers during the Patum, a festival in Berga, Spain, on Sunday. Catalonia’s independence drive has imbued the Patum, like so many other cultural symbols and expressions in the region, with ever greater nationalist significance for Catalans.

title: Perfect Strangers: Maya Rudolph and Vanessa Beecroft
abstract: The master impersonator, whose new show, “Maya and Marty,” starts today, plays a game of free association with the outspoken performance artist.

title: Airport Near Everest Is Its Own Perilous Adventure
abstract: Planes heading to Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Lukla, Nepal, often have to deal with high wind and thick fog. Then pilots face a short, sloping runway.

multimedia_item.caption: A plane landing at Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Lukla, Nepal. The airport, the closest one to Mount Everest, challenges pilots with its weather and short, sloped runway.

abstract: The fashion house flew in celebrities and some of its best customers for an elaborate show an embattled country.

title: One-Thing Shops: Soda, Los Angeles
abstract: Galco’s in Highland Park, which opened in 1897, carries over 750 varieties and draws visitors from around the world.

multimedia_item.caption: John Nese, the owner of Galco’s Old World Grocery, stands in the aisles among some of the 750 soda variety he carries. Once a neighborhood Italian grocery, Galco’s has evolved into a soda specialty shop that draws visitors from around the world.

title: Great Plains Energy Agrees to Buy Westar for $8.6 Billion

title: An A.F.C. Wimbledon Movie Could Be Titled ‘Phoenix Rising’
abstract: The Wimbledon club, which was founded only 14 years ago when Wimbledon F.C. left town, has won promotion to the third tier of English soccer.

multimedia_item.caption: Adebayo Akinfenwa, right, and Andy Barcham celebrated Akinfenwa’s penalty kick in stoppage time. A.F.C. Wimbledon defeated Plymouth Argyle, 2-0, to win promotion to England’s third-tier League One.
